author: By Jenny Block
title: Honoring Tradition, and Personal Choice, With a Persian Wedding Custom
description: The Sofreh Aghd is a symbolic wedding display that involves a variety of rituals. But many couples are choosing to add their own modern twist.
content: Weddings are steeped in tradition, but where do those rituals come from? “Traditions,” a new column, explores the origins of various wedding customs from around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sushma Subramanian
title: In Brazil, Beauty Is a Right. Are They On To Something?
description: Brazil’s unique plastic surgery subsidies represent the country’s view that beauty is a form of self-care.
content: Every person with a toddler knows that her child is in constant imminent peril. Trying to prevent the next near-death or disfiguring accident is a parent’s unending occupation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Alabama Woman Missing After Stopping to Help a Child on a Highway
description: Carlee Russell told a 911 dispatcher on Thursday night that there was a toddler walking along the side of an interstate, the police said. She has not been seen since.
content: A 25-year-old woman in Alabama was last heard from on Thursday night after telling a 911 dispatcher that she saw a toddler walking along the side of an interstate and would pull over to help, prompting a sprawling search for her as investigators raced to find clues about her disappearance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Can A.I. Invent?
description: A group of legal experts are pressing patent agencies, courts and policymakers to address the question as generative A.I. seems on the brink of invading another uniquely human endeavor.
content: Generative artificial intelligence, the technology engine powering the popular ChatGPT chatbot, seems to have a limitless bag of tricks. It can produce on command everything from recipes and vacation plans to computer code and molecules for new drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Carlos Alberto Montaner, Prominent Critic of Castro’s Cuba, Dies at 80
description: After fleeing the island in 1961, he became one of the leading voices of opposition against the country’s Communist dictatorship.
content: Carlos Alberto Montaner, a writer who escaped Cuba shortly after its Communist revolution, then built a career as one of the exile community’s leading opponents of the Castro regime, died on June 29 at his home in Madrid. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kolker
title: The Gilgo Beach Victims Were Always More Than Escorts
description: From the beginning, the women who were found murdered were reduced to being prostitutes. More than a decade after they went missing, that seems to have changed.
content: Twelve years ago, on the Monday after Easter in 2011, on a gray afternoon in New London, Conn., Melissa Cann sat at a picnic table on a pier, talking about her big sister, Maureen Brainard-Barnes, who disappeared on a trip to Manhattan four years earlier. While Ms. Cann described herself as a homebody, she said that her older sister was a free spirit, artistic, daring and often clashing with their mother. Maureen had worked as a blackjack dealer, as a clerk at a ShopRite and, in the six months or so before she vanished, as an escort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: In Hollywood, the Strikes Are Just Part of the Problem
description: The entertainment industry is trying to figure out the economics of streaming. It’s also facing angst over a tech-powered future and fighting to stay culturally dominant.
content: Existential hand-wringing has always been part of Hollywood’s personality. But the crisis in which the entertainment capital now finds itself is different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Netanyahu Says He’s ‘Very Well’ After Being Rushed to Hospital
description: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said he was feeling better on Saturday after feeling dizzy and rushing to the hospital. Mr. Netanyahu, 73, is currently facing one of the most testing phases of his political career.
content: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, said he was feeling “very well” on Saturday evening after experiencing mild dizziness and being rushed to a hospital for examination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Watch Out for the Fake Tom Cruise
description: Hollywood is about to get even more phony!
content: WASHINGTON — In the 2002 movie “Simone,” Al Pacino plays a director whose star, played by Winona Ryder, walks out on him after saying her trailer on set isn’t grand enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni, Bernhard Warner, Ravi Mattu and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Why Deep-Sea Mining Is the Next Battleground in the Energy Transition
description: Countries and companies are in a fight between those that want to excavate minerals used in electric vehicles and others that warn the cost is too high.
content: Surging demand for metals used in electric vehicle batteries has kicked off an international race to mine the deep seas. And there are no rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Lange
title: Furby, Is That You?
description: The animatronic toy got a makeover. It’s getting mixed reviews.
content: The original Furby, released in 1998, had the head of an owl, the beak of a chicken, the feet of a cat, the ears of a pig, the fur of a rabbit, the mohawk of a tufted titmouse and the eyes of a robot, which it was — a robot that whirred, clacked, spoke a made-up language called Furbish and, famously, never turned off (unless its batteries were removed).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: America’s Foreign Vacations Tell Us Something About the U.S. Economy
description: Prices are high, but Americans are opening their wallets for international flights and hotels. It’s the latest evidence of consumer resilience.
content: Forget Emily. These days, a whole flood of Americans are in Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: ‘For the Love of the Water’: Tours for the Swimming-Obsessed
description: Swimming island to island in the Adriatic, gliding over coral reefs in the Caribbean, dipping into Iceland’s freezing waters and steamy hot springs: Travel companies are building entire tours around organized swims.
content: During the pandemic, when Miriam Leitko couldn’t swim because pools were closed, the lifelong swimmer built a lap pool at her home in Willis, Texas. As soon as travel restrictions were lifted in 2021, she signed up for a weeklong trip to Hawaii with SwimVacation, a Maine-based tour operator that specializes in open-water swimming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Meridith Kohut
title: In the Land of Football, a Cricket Oasis Rises Outside Houston
description: The game of cricket has taken hold in Texas’ largest city, as a culture of sports competition meets a growing South Asian population.
content: Drive northwest out of Houston, and as cow pastures wrestle back the flat expanse from the city’s tentacled sprawl, there arise along the road, suddenly, improbably, many, many cricket fields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Ons Jabeur Calls Wimbledon Loss ‘the Most Painful’ of Her Career
description: “Honestly, I felt a lot of pressure, feeling a lot of stress,” Jabeur said after losing the women’s singles final to Marketa Vondrousova.
content: With the hopes of a country, a continent and a world of tennis lovers who felt she was long overdue urging her toward history, Ons Jabeur fell agonizingly short. For the second time at Wimbledon, and the third time in a year at a Grand Slam, Jabeur had hoped to become the first woman from Tunisia, the first from Africa and the first Arabic speaker to win a major women’s singles tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Melvin Wulf, Transformative Civil Liberties Lawyer, Dies at 95
description: As legal director for 15 years, he made the A.C.L.U. a more aggressive organization and worked with Ruth Bader Ginsburg before she became a United States Supreme Court justice.
content: Melvin Wulf, a constitutional lawyer who reshaped the American Civil Liberties Union into a more aggressive litigator, argued 10 cases before the United States Supreme Court and supported the future Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in bringing a landmark sex discrimination case, died on July 8 at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Where Spies Work
description: Jeff Chen’s themeless grid is stacked with surprises.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Jeff Chen is a prolific constructor who collaborates with seemingly everyone in the puzzleverse, including Jim Horne on the indispensable crossword statistics site xwordinfo.com. This is his first solo Saturday grid since 2017; its design is complex (with unusual left-right mirror symmetry), and there’s a ton of wild fill, as one would expect from a guru.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louis Lucero II
title: Barbie: A Visual Dictionary
description: The things that make Barbie Barbie.
content: Maybe you’ve heard there’s a Barbie movie coming out?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin and Rebecca Carballo
title: 4 Dead and Gunman at Large in Georgia Shooting, Police Say
description: The police said there were four different crime scenes in Hampton, Ga., south of Atlanta. The gunman’s connections to the victims and motive were unknown.
content: The police were searching for a gunman who they say killed four people in a Georgia suburb on Saturday morning in a shooting with no known motive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Luke Broadwater
title: With a Centrist Manifesto, No Labels Pushes Its Presidential Bid Forward
description: The bipartisan group, facing enormous opposition from Democrats, hopes a new policy document will advance its political cause — and possible third-party White House run.
content: A new political platform focused on cooperative governance by the bipartisan group No Labels has something for everyone to embrace — and just as much for both sides to reject.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Russian Forces Are Doing ‘Everything They Can’ to Stop Counteroffensive, Zelensky Says
description: The Ukrainian leader has secured new weapons pledges, but it was not clear when the aid would arrive, or how consequential it would be on the battlefield.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that Russian forces were throwing “everything they can” at Kyiv’s troops fighting to retake land in the south and east, again emphasizing the grueling nature of a counteroffensive that is moving more slowly than some allies had hoped and later stressing the importance of their continued support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Marga Minco, Who Chronicled Jewish Life in Wartime, Dies at 103
description: Her first and best-known book, “Het Bittere Kruid” (“Bitter Herbs”), described her experiences as a young woman after the Nazi invasion of the Netherlands in 1940.
content: Marga Minco, a Dutch novelist who was one of the last of a generation of European Holocaust authors whose works are widely considered literary classics, died on Monday at her home in Amsterdam. She was 103.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea’s Monsoon Rains Set Off Deadly Landslides and Flooding
description: The current monsoon season is already proving to be a particularly deadly one in South Korea, with rain forecast to continue.
content: Five bodies were discovered in a bus trapped by floodwaters in an underpass in a city south of the South Korean capital, Seoul, on Sunday. The country has been reeling from intense rainfall from the monsoon, which has swept across the nation in recent days, burying homes, knocking down trees, canceling flights and trains, and cutting power to tens of thousands of residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: The Game Is Afoot
description: Michael Schlossberg’s Sunday puzzle merrily marches along.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Poland Doesn’t Want Migrants, but These Foreign Workers Are Welcome
description: A tiny village is taking in 6,000 laborers from Asia. They are needed by a petroleum company controlled by the right-wing government, which has vowed to keep migrants out.
content: Determined to resist a European Union plan to spread the burden of migrants and asylum seekers around the continent, Poland’s prime minister, Mateusz Morawiecki, says his country wants to ensure that “Poles can safely walk the streets,” so it will not take in foreigners it does not want.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: The Weather by the Numbers
description: Lots of triple-digit numbers tell the story of the early summer’s torrid heat wave.
content: A suffocating heat wave has swept across the South and Southwest in the United States, bringing dangerous temperatures and breaking heat records. Here’s what the numbers tell us about the heat and how it is affecting Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Nate Schweber
title: Suspect in Gilgo Beach Killings Led a Life of Chaos and Control
description: Rex Heuermann was painstaking in his Manhattan professional pursuits. At home in Massapequa Park, he left neighbors discomfited.
content: At his office near the Empire State Building, Rex Heuermann was a master of the meticulous: a veteran architectural consultant and a self-styled expert at navigating the intricacies of New York City’s building code. He impressed some clients and drove others crazy with his fine-toothed directives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Andrew E. Kramer and Eric Schmitt
title: After Suffering Heavy Losses, Ukrainians Paused to Rethink Strategy
description: Early in the counteroffensive, Ukraine lost as much as 20 percent of its weapons and armor. The rate dropped as the campaign slowed and commanders shifted tactics.
content: In the first two weeks of Ukraine’s grueling counteroffensive, as much as 20 percent of the weaponry it sent to the battlefield was damaged or destroyed, according to American and European officials. The toll includes some of the formidable Western fighting machines — tanks and armored personnel carriers — the Ukrainians were counting on to beat back the Russians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: New York Has $1.1 Billion to Fight Flooding. Will It Be Enough?
description: “It’s kind of like we’re patching the boat but it’s already filling up with water,” one climate researcher said.
content: For Franco Montalto, a flooding expert and engineer, decades of research were suddenly amplified by a real-life emergency in the Adirondacks, where he and his family were on vacation this week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: U.A.W. Talks Quite Likely to Be Testy
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 15, 2023.
content: “We are seeing in very diverse workplaces a new interest in unions and a willingness to strike. What we don’t know yet is how large this movement is going to become and how far it is going to go.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: How to Break a Country
description: A road trip through Eastern Europe underscores how Putin has diminished Russia.
content: TALLINN, Estonia — Vladimir Putin has compared himself to the czar Peter the Great. But to travel through Eastern Europe is to see how much he has instead caused Russian influence to shrink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Robert Gebeloff
title: They Lost Their Legs. Doctors and Health Care Giants Profited.
description: Medical device makers have bankrolled a cottage industry of doctors and clinics that perform artery-clearing procedures that can lead to amputations.
content: Kelly Hanna’s leg was amputated on a summer day in 2020, after a Michigan doctor who called himself the “leg saver” had damaged her arteries by snaking metal wires through them to clear away plaque.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: What to Watch in the 2024 Money Wars as a Big Deadline Arrives
description: Which presidential and Senate candidates are swimming in cash? Which ones are growing desperate? That and more is becoming clearer on Saturday, when campaigns must file their latest federal reports.
content: The financial landscape of the 2024 presidential race — the contest’s haves and have-nots, their momentum and desperation — is coming into sharper focus on Saturday, the deadline for campaigns to file their latest reports to the Federal Election Commission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Rare Dinosaur ‘Bonebed’ Is Discovered in a Maryland Park
description: Experts said it could be the widest-ranging discovery of fossils of different species on the East Coast.
content: Fossils from animals including dinosaurs and stingrays more than 100 million years old were uncovered in a Maryland park in what experts said could be the widest-ranging discovery of fossils of different species on the East Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Frank Gehry Returns to the Streets of His Canadian Childhood
description: The renowned architect was back in Toronto for the start of construction on his second project in the city where he was born and raised.
content: Frank Gehry, the architect whose free-form Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, redefined architecture and set off a surge in museum construction in the late 1990s, was recently back in Toronto, celebrating the beginning of a new project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Canadian Politicians Who Criticize China Become Its Targets
description: As China increases its reach in diaspora communities, Chinese Canadian politicians in Vancouver are the focus of Chinese state interference in Canadian politics.
content: The polls predicted a re-election victory, maybe even a landslide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: The U.S. and China Are Restarting Climate Talks: Here’s Where Things Stand
description: John Kerry travels to Beijing for three days of talks, as the world’s two biggest economies, and two biggest polluters, try to cooperate on climate action.
content: For nearly a year, talks between the planet’s two biggest polluters, China and the United States, have been suspended as the impacts of global warming have only grown more intense in the form of deadly heat, drought, floods and wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Marketa Vondrousova Wins Wimbledon and Her First Grand Slam Title
description: Vondrousova of the Czech Republic overpowered Ons Jabeur of Tunisia in the first set and never looked back, winning 6-4, 6-4.
content: Marketa Vondrousova of the Czech Republic, among the most unlikely of Wimbledon champions, is unlikely no more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israeli Reservists Threaten Mass Resignations if Judicial Plan Proceeds
description: Military reserves are critical to Israel’s operational readiness. Reservists are again using that leverage against the government’s effort to curb judicial power.
content: At least 180 senior fighter pilots, elite commandos and cyber-intelligence specialists in the Israeli military reserve have informed their commanders that they will no longer report for volunteer duty if the government proceeds with a plan to limit judicial influence by the end of the month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Wilson
title: Summer Birthdays, Casablanca and Boreal Forests
description: A critic recommends old and new books.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Turner and Eric Nagourney
title: Home Is Where the Horses Are for a Threatened Culture
description: The Appleby Horse Fair draws tens of thousands of Gypsies and Irish Travellers each year to a rural patch of England to celebrate their culture. Our photographer spent four days there.
content: There is the world, and then there is Appleby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: How a Rocky, Inhospitable Place Became a Beacon of Calm
description: In “Returning Light,” Robert L. Harris reflects on his many years as the caretaker of a lonely outpost off the west coast of Ireland.
content: When he first comes upon the advertisement for a job opening on a remote island eight miles off the coast of western Ireland, Robert L. Harris is already primed for sublimity. Visiting a friend in the area in 1985, two years earlier, he and his wife had impulsively joined a small group of tourists heading to Skellig Michael. As the boat nears the island, seabirds wheel in the sky, and everything changes:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Was She Murdered? Kidnapped? Or Did She Fake Her Own Disappearance?
description: In Polly Stewart’s novel, “The Good Ones,” a professor investigates what happened when her best friend vanished 20 years earlier.
content: This month’s books all feature women making bad decisions — about themselves, about other people and about how to confront the threats swirling around them. Each is unwise in her own interesting way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Kornelis
title: Tiffany Haddish Dances to the Beat of Her Never-Ending Internal Soundtrack
description: The actress employs grapeseed oil for rough skin and an Eddie Murphy classic for rough days.
content: This summer, Tiffany Haddish plays a marijuana-smoking cat (“The Freak Brothers”), a detective pulled out of retirement (“The Afterparty”), a psychic in a film based on a Disneyland ride (“Haunted Mansion”) and the mother of a child who broadcasts his love life to aliens (“Landscape With Invisible Hand”). For her, the mom is the most relatable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Women React to News About an Over-the-Counter Birth Control Pill
description: Most potential consumers were excited by the prospect, though sticker price and safety were lingering concerns.
content: On Thursday, the Food and Drug Administration approved a hormonal birth control pill, called Opill, to be sold over the counter — a landmark decision that was largely received with excitement by many women and teenage girls in New York. The pill will be sold in stores and online, without age restrictions, beginning early next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to This American Life: The Florida Experiment
description: What’s it like in Ron DeSantis’s Florida?
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Turmoil in Florida’s New State Guard, as Some Recruits Quit
description: Some who volunteered for the force commissioned by Gov. Ron DeSantis said the group, billed as a natural disaster relief organization, had become too militarized.
content: Early last summer, complaining that Washington had failed to provide adequate staffing for Florida’s National Guard, Gov. Ron DeSantis announced that for the first time in 75 years he was activating the State Guard, a force of volunteers that could respond to hurricanes and other public emergencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Everett Mendelsohn, Who Linked Science and Society, Dies at 91
description: A longtime professor at Harvard, he lectured on atom bombs, genetics and more, examining how science, culture and politics influence one another.
content: Everett I. Mendelsohn, a longtime Harvard professor who as a scholar of the history of science explored how the evolution of science has been influenced by historical and cultural trends and vice versa, died on June 6 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At the University of Chicago: Was It Free Speech, or Harassment?
description: Readers react to a conservative student’s attempts to shut down a course called “The Problem of Whiteness.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das and Victor Mather
title: Lionel Messi Signs With Inter Miami, Starting New Era for M.L.S.
description: Messi is expected to join the team this week on a contract that runs through the 2025 Major League Soccer season.
content: The greatest soccer player of his era, and maybe the greatest of all time, is coming to the United States for the twilight of his career. Lionel Messi, 36, officially joined Inter Miami of Major League Soccer, the club announced in a release on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Why Sunscreen Is the Only Anti-Aging Product You Need
description: The sun’s rays cause the majority of skin changes as you grow older. Here’s how sunscreen helps prevent the damage.
content: Have you ever looked at the skin on the buttocks of a 90-year-old? Dr. Fayne Frey has. “It’s beautiful,” said the dermatologist and author of the book “The Skincare Hoax.” “There’s very little pigment, there’s very little wrinkling, there are very few blood vessels.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Reconsidering the Staycation
description: You don’t necessarily have to travel to experience the benefits of a summer vacation.
content: I’ve always been skeptical of the staycation. The coinage is too cute for what feels like a consolation prize: While other people are off exploring the Blue Lagoon by camper van, you get to stay in your very own home and go to your usual supermarket for Cheerios!
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 15, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 15, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about federal prosecutors’ inquiry into President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election misstated who first made public a recording of Stephen Bannon, a former adviser to Mr. Trump, telling associates that Mr. Trump was going to summarily declare he had won. The recording was first reported by Mother Jones, not the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Tressler
title: Wasting Away With Rachael Ray
description: The stars of the Food Network help a teenage patient make it through the long days in the hospital with no solid food.
content: When I was 15, I fell in love with the voice of Rachael Ray. That velvety contralto was the soundtrack of my days in the children’s hospital I hated — with its plaid curtains and kind nurses — but called home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: ‘And Just Like That,’ Everyone Is Part of the 1 Percent
description: ‘Sex and the City’ explored complications of work, money and identity that are missing from the reboot.
content: In honor of the 25th anniversary of the debut of “Sex and the City,” The Cut posted a set of memes from the show on Instagram, including some of the series’ most recognizable lines. When I saw the one about Miranda — “She was a lawyer. He was a sandwich.” — I finally realized what I missed most about the original series that is absent in its reboot, “And Just Like That …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Eduardo Medina
title: Police Capture ‘Survivalist’ Murder Suspect Who Escaped Jail
description: The police said that the escapee, Michael Burham, was found in the woods on Saturday in a “worn-out” state, with his clothes dirty and wet.
content: The manhunt for a murder suspect who escaped from a Pennsylvania jail on July 6 by tying bedsheets together to climb down from a roof ended on Saturday when the suspect was captured by the police, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Rent-Controlled vs. Rent-Stabilized: How Much Can a Landlord Charge?
description: Owners of the city’s roughly 16,000 rent-controlled homes can raise the rent, but only so often, and only by so much.
content: Q: I live in a rent-controlled apartment on the Upper West Side, and I’d like to know what the rent increase will be this year. I have read a lot about the increases for rent-stabilized apartments issued by New York’s Rent Guidelines Board, but for not rent-controlled apartments. Is there an increase, and will it be retroactive? Will we receive formal notice from a government agency, or is a note from the landlord enough?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: They Put Down Roots In Small-Town Vermont. Then the River Reared Up.
description: Bex Prasse and Craig Kovalsky had worked nearly a year to restore a rundown building so they could open a gourmet deli. The river behind it had other plans.
content: For nearly a year, Bex Prasse and Craig Kovalsky had labored to restore every inch of the run-down building where they envisioned their future business, on an up-and-coming Main Street in the small Vermont ski town of Ludlow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: The Southwest Braces for Record-Breaking Heat
description: The National Weather Service forecast 45 record-high temperatures across the country, mostly in the Southwest, ahead of the weekend.
content: People across the southwestern United States were trying to stay cool on Saturday as a punishing heat wave was posed to break temperature records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Search for a Century-Old Shipwreck Turns Up One Even Older
description: Researchers and a television crew were looking for two naval ships lost in Lake Superior a century ago. Instead, they found a tugboat that mysteriously sank in 1879.
content: In September, a Discovery Channel film crew traveled to Paradise, Mich., searching for two French naval ships that disappeared in 1918. But on a voyage to find them, they stumbled upon another shipwreck that was four decades older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, July 8-14
description: No amount of exhortation could help with this week’s toughest word.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sriram Krishnan
title: You’re Not Imagining It: Social Media Is in Chaos
description: It is a sign that the industry is undergoing a major shift.
content: War is breaking out on social media, and it could radically change how the internet works and how we experience it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Buchanan
title: His Sexuality Doesn’t Define Him, but It Can Set Him Apart
description: Eric Bach is an openly gay broadcaster for the Fredericksburg Nationals. He has major league aspirations, but his path has been much lonelier than he would prefer.
content: The hateful email was a surprise, but for Eric Bach, it was not entirely unexpected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Stuart A. Thompson
title: ‘Not for Machines to Harvest’: Data Revolts Break Out Against A.I.
description: Fed up with A.I. companies consuming online content without consent, fan fiction writers, actors, social media companies and news organizations are among those rebelling.
content: For more than 20 years, Kit Loffstadt has written fan fiction exploring alternate universes for “Star Wars” heroes and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” villains, sharing her stories free online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Carlos Alcaraz Gets a Shot at Novak Djokovic in Wimbledon Singles Final
description: “For Novak, it is one more day, one more moment,” Alcaraz said of Sunday’s final. “For me, it’s going to be the best moment of my life, I think.”
content: If Carlos Alcaraz were more patient, perhaps he could just wait for Novak Djokovic to fade away. At 20, Alcaraz is 16 years younger than the great champion, and the day is likely to come when Djokovic is either retired or in decline, and Alcaraz can claim the tennis kingdom as his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Gorman
title: Amanda Gorman: In Memory of Those Still in the Water
description: By writing an elegy through the words of history, I hope to unearth, or unwater, the dead from beneath a mass of waves.
content: On June 14, 2023, the migrant boat Adriana capsized off the coast of Greece, killing more than 600 men, women and children who had been crammed onboard the trawler by traffickers. As investigations by the BBC and The New York Times have revealed, officials and coast guard crews failed to treat the crisis as a rescue mission until the last few hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaya Laterman
title: How a Master of Japanese Ink Painting Spends Her Sundays
description: Koho Yamamoto studied her art in an internment camp for Japanese Americans during World War II and then opened a school. At 101, she still finds time to teach.
content: “People keep making me older every day,” said Masako Yamamoto, who is 101. “I don’t remember my age anymore, so I’m surprised when people say how old I am.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Case Against Rex Heuermann: Read the Document
description: Suffolk County, N.Y., prosecutors argued against bail for Mr. Heuermann in a 32-page document that explicitly details the investigation into the Gilgo Beach killings. The New York Times has redacted phone numbers, email addresses, personal addresses and the names of private social media accounts. It has also redacted offensive material that was included in Mr. Heuermann’s internet searches.
content: Suffolk County, N.Y., prosecutors argued against bail for Mr. Heuermann in a 32-page document that explicitly details the investigation into the Gilgo Beach killings. The New York Times has redacted phone numbers, email addresses, personal addresses and the names of private social media accounts.
